To achieve everlasting life without end. If the half-*liang* dosage is insufficient to ascend to heaven, it merely grants longevity and immortality. Further, blend the gold water and mercury with yellow earth, then refine them with intense fire for one day—all will transform into gold. If refined for two days, it will entirely become an elixir. However, when blending with yellow earth and firing, place charcoal at the base to prevent the yellow earth from turning into gold and forming the Returned Elixir. Once the elixir is complete, it should be dispersed. If one fears that gold mixed with yellow earth in a crucible might be refined into the Returned Elixir as described above, an alternative method yields what is called *Bi Xian* ("Avoidance Immortal"). Consuming it in the size of a small bean allows one to enter famous mountains and great waters, thereby becoming an immortal. *Bi Xian* means "to avoid death." The texts state that it only enables avoidance of grain and longevity, not ascent to heaven. Thus, one enters famous mountains and great waters to become an immortal. Earth immortals become spirits of mountains and rivers, such as the Youth of the Eastern Sea or the Lords of the Five Peaks. Those who enter great waters do not literally submerge but rather take the great waters as their domain, akin to the Prefect of the Southern Sea. *Baopuzi’s Scripture of Divine Immortals and Golden Liquor, Volume One* concludes here.

chunks.original_text: 神仙论金丹 抱朴子日：余考览养性之书，鸠集久视之方，曾所披涉篇卷，以千计矣，莫不以还丹金液为大要焉。 然此二事，盖仙道之极也。 服此不仙，则古无仙矣。 往者国土丧乱，莫不奔播四出。 余周旋徐豫荆湘江广数州之问，阅见流移道士数百人矣。 或有素闻其名，乃在云日之表者，然率相似如一，其所知见深浅有无，不足以相倾也。 各各有数十卷经书，亦未必能悉解之也，为写畜之耳。 时有知行气断谷，服诸草木药法，所有方书，略为同文，无一人不有《道机经》，唯以此为至秘，乃云是尹喜所撰。 余告之日：此是近世魏军督王图所撰耳，非古人也。 图了不知大药，正欲行气入室求仙，此道机为道，毕於此，此复是误人之甚。 余问诸道士以神丹金液之事，及《三皇内文》，召天地神祇之法，了无一人知之。 其夸诞自誉，及欺人云：已久寿，及言曾与仙人共游者，将太半矣。 足学尽微者甚缈。 或有颇闻有金丹，而不谓今世复有得之者，皆言唯上古已度仙人，乃当晓之。 或有得丹方外说，不得其真经。 或得杂碎丹方，便谓丹法尽於此矣。 昔左元放於天柱山中精思，而神人受之以金丹仙经。 会汉末大乱，不遑合作，避地来江束，志欲投之於名山，以修斯道。 余从祖仙公，又从元放受之。 凡受《太清丹经》三卷，及《九鼎丹经》一卷，《金液丹经》一卷。 余师郑君，余从祖仙公之弟子也。 又於从祖受之，而家贫无用置药。 余亲事之，洒扫积久，乃於马边山中，立坛盟受之，并口诀不书者。 江束先无此书，此书出左元放授余从祖，从祖以授郑君，郑君授余。 故他道士了无知者。 然余受已二十余年矣。
chunks.translated_text:
**On Divine Immortals and the Golden Elixir**

*Baopuzi* states: In my study of texts on nurturing life and my compilation of methods for prolonging vision, I have perused thousands of scrolls. None fail to regard the reverted elixir and golden liquor as the paramount essentials. Yet these two arts represent the ultimate of the immortal’s Dao. If consuming them does not lead to transcendence, then immortals have never existed.

In earlier times, the realm was ravaged by chaos, and all fled in every direction. I traveled through the regions of Xu, Yu, Jing, Xiang, Jiang, and Guang, encountering hundreds of wandering Daoist adepts. Some were figures whose names I had long heard, men who dwelled beyond the clouds and sun. Yet they were nearly indistinguishable from one another—none possessed knowledge or insight profound enough to surpass the rest. Each carried dozens of scriptures, though few could fully comprehend them; they merely copied and preserved them.

Some knew methods of circulating *qi*, abstaining from grains, or ingesting herbal medicines. Their manuals were largely uniform, and not one lacked the *Scripture of the Dao’s Mechanism*, which they regarded as the utmost secret, claiming it was authored by Yin Xi. I told them: This was composed by Wang Tu, a military supervisor of Wei in recent times—not an ancient. Wang Tu knew nothing of the great elixir; he merely sought transcendence through *qi*-circulation and chamber practices. The *Dao’s Mechanism* exhausts itself in this pursuit and misleads others gravely.

When I questioned these Daoists about the golden elixir, golden liquor, the *Inner Writings of the Three Sovereigns*, or the methods for summoning the spirits of heaven and earth, not one knew of them. Most boasted and praised themselves, deceiving others by claiming extraordinary longevity or past associations with immortals. Those who had mastered even the subtlest learning were exceedingly rare. Some had heard of the golden elixir but denied its attainment in the present age, insisting only the immortals of high antiquity could have understood it. Others possessed external explanations of elixir formulas but not the true scriptures, or they held fragmentary elixir methods and believed these encompassed the entirety of the art.

Long ago, Zuo Yuanfang meditated in seclusion at Mount Tianzhu, where a divine being bestowed upon him the *Scripture of the Golden Elixir and Divine Immortals*. Amid the great upheaval of the Han’s end, he had no opportunity to compound it. Fleeing to the lands east of the Jiang, he resolved to entrust it to a renowned mountain and cultivate this Dao. My great-uncle, the Immortal Master, received it from Yuanfang. In all, he was given three scrolls of the *Great Clarity Scripture of the Elixir*, one scroll of the *Scripture of the Nine-Cauldron Elixir*, and one scroll of the *Scripture of the Golden Liquor Elixir*.

My teacher, Master Zheng, was a disciple of my great-uncle, the Immortal Master. I received the teachings from my great-uncle as well, but our family’s poverty prevented us from procuring the ingredients. I served Master Zheng personally, sweeping and attending to him for many years, until at last, in the mountains beside Ma’s Edge, I erected an altar, swore an oath, and received the transmission—including the oral instructions not recorded in writing. These scriptures were previously unknown east of the Jiang. They originated with Zuo Yuanfang, who transmitted them to my great-uncle, who passed them to Master Zheng, who then bestowed them upon me. Thus, no other Daoists knew of them. Yet it has been over twenty years since I received them.

chunks.original_text: 资无饭石，无以为之，但有长叹耳。 有积金盈柜，聚钱若山者，复不知有此不死之法。 就令问之，亦万无一言。 如何。 夫饮玉粕则知浆蒋之薄味，睹昆仑则觉丘埋之至卑。 既览金丹之道，则使人不欲复视小小之方。 然大药卒难得办为当，且御小者，以自支持耳。 然服他药百斛，为能小小益，而终不能使人长生也。 故《老君口诀》云：子不得还丹金液，虚自苦耳。 夫五谷犹能活人，得之则生，绝之则死，又死於上品之神药，其益人岂不万倍於五谷耶。 夫金丹之为物，烧之愈久，变化愈妙。 黄金入火，百炼不销，埋之毕天不朽。 服此二药，炼人身体，故能令人不老不死。 此盖假借外物，以自坚固。 有如脂之养火，而可以不灭耳。 铜青涂脚，入水不腐。 此是借铜之劲，以抒其肉也。 金丹入身中，沾洽荣卫，非但铜青之外传矣。 世问多不信至道者，则悠悠者皆是耳。 然万一时偶有好事者，而复不见此法，不值明师，无由闻天下之有斯妙事也。 余今略抄金丹之都较，以示后人同志者，勤求之，不可守浅近之方，而谓之足，以办度世也。 遂不遇之者，直当息意於无穷之冀耳，想见其说，必如出演污而浮沧海，背萤磷而向日月，闻雷霆而觉布鼓之陋，见巨鲸而知寸纱之细也，其喽喽无所先入。 欲以弊药，必规升腾者，何异策赛驴而欲寻迅风，棹舰舟而欲济大川乎。 又诸小饵丹方甚多，然法有深浅，力势不同，其优劣转不相及，犹一酸之酒，不可以方九酝之醇耳。 然小丹之下者，犹自远胜草木之上者也。 凡草木之物，烧即糜烂。 而丹砂烧之，则成水银，积变又还成丹，其去凡药亦远矣。 故能令人长生，而神人独见此理矣。 其去俗人，一何缅邈之无垠乎。 世人少所识，多所怪。 或不知水银出於丹砂，告之终不肯信。 云丹砂本赤物，从何得成此白物。 又云丹砂是石耳，今烧诸石皆成灰，而丹砂何得独尔。 此近易之事，犹不可喻。 其闻神仙之道而大笑之，不亦宜乎。 上古真人，愍念将来之可教者，为作方法委曲，欲使其免死亡之祸，可谓至矣。 然而俗民不肯信，谓为虚文。 若是虚文者，焉得九转九变，日数所成，皆如方耶。 真人所以知此者，诚不可以庸夫近思求也。 余好方术，负涉请问，不惮睑远，每有异闻，则以为喜。 虽见毁笑，不以为恶。 焉知来者不如今，是以着此，以示识者，岂苟尚奇怪，而崇饰空言。 欲令书行於世，信结流俗哉。 盛阳不能荣枯朽，上．智不能移下愚。 书为信者传，事为识者贵。 农夫得彤弓以驱乌，南夷得一表衣以负薪。 夫不知者，复何可强哉。 世人饱食终日，复未必能勤儒墨之业，治进德之务。 但其逍遥游遨，以尽年月。 其所营也，非荣则利。 或飞苍走黄，或流连梧觞，或以美女荒沈丝竹，或耽沦绮执，或控弦以疲筋骨，或博弈以弃功夫。 闻至道之言而如醉，睹道论而昼睡，有身不恪，动之死地，不肯求问养生之法，自欲割削之，一烈熬之，憔悴之，洒吃之。 而有道者自宝，秘其所知，无求於人，亦安肯强行语之乎。 世人常言，咸以长生，若可求得者，古之圣人以之富贵者，当得之，而无得者，是无此道也。 而不知古之富贵者，亦今之富贵，正同耳。 俱不信不求，而皆以目前之所欲者为急，亦安能得之耶。
chunks.translated_text:
Without the means to procure even the simplest ingredients, what can one do but sigh in despair? Those who hoard gold to fill their chests and amass wealth like mountains know nothing of this deathless art. Even if asked, they would not utter a single word. How could they?

One who has tasted jade dregs knows the insipidity of mere broth; one who has gazed upon Kunlun perceives the utter baseness of lowly mounds. Having glimpsed the Way of the Golden Elixir, one no longer desires to regard petty formulas. Yet the great medicine is difficult to obtain in full—thus, one makes do with lesser remedies to sustain oneself for the time being. Consuming a hundred measures of other drugs may yield slight benefit, but none can grant immortality.

As the *Oral Instructions of Lord Lao* states: "Without the Returning Elixir or Golden Liquor, you labor in vain." Even the five grains sustain life—obtain them, and you live; be deprived of them, and you die. How much more potent, then, are the supreme spirit medicines, which surpass the five grains a myriadfold?

The Golden Elixir, when refined, grows ever more wondrous with time. Gold enters fire yet remains unmelting through a hundred smeltings; buried, it does not decay for all eternity. These two medicines refine the human body, enabling one to escape old age and death. This is but borrowing external substances to fortify oneself—like fat nourishing flame, allowing it to burn without end. Copper verdigris applied to wood keeps it from rotting in water; here, the strength of copper is lent to preserve the flesh. When the Golden Elixir enters the body, it permeates the meridians and nourishes the constructive and defensive qi—far beyond the mere external transmission of copper verdigris.

Most in the world do not believe in the supreme Way; such are the idle and indifferent. Yet if by chance there arises one with the inclination, who never encounters this method, never meets an enlightened teacher, how shall they learn of such wondrous matters? I have here briefly transcribed the essentials of the Golden Elixir to show those of like mind among later generations. Seek diligently, and do not cling to shallow formulas, deeming them sufficient for transcending the world.

Those who never encounter it must simply rest their hopes in boundless possibility. To hear of it is like emerging from filth to float upon the vast sea, turning from fireflies to face the sun and moon, hearing thunder and recognizing the crudeness of a drum, or seeing a leviathan and knowing the insignificance of a silkworm’s thread. How could one, with such paltry beginnings, hope to ascend? To seek transcendence with inferior medicines is like spurring a lame donkey to chase the swift wind or paddling a raft to cross a great river.

There are many minor elixir formulas, but their methods vary in depth, their potency in strength. Their efficacy differs as greatly as a single brew of wine cannot compare to nine fermentations of fine liquor. Even the least of these minor elixirs far surpasses the finest of herbal medicines. All plants and trees, when burned, turn to ash; cinnabar, when heated, becomes mercury, and through repeated refinement, reverts to cinnabar—so distant is it from common drugs. Thus it grants long life, and only the divine perceive this principle. How immeasurably remote is this from the understanding of the vulgar!

The world knows little and finds much strange. Some do not know that mercury comes from cinnabar; tell them, and they refuse to believe. "Cinnabar is red," they say, "how can it become this white substance?" Or, "Cinnabar is but a stone—all stones turn to ash when burned, so why should cinnabar be different?" If such simple matters cannot be grasped, is it any wonder they laugh at the Way of immortality?

The true ones of antiquity, pitying those of later ages who might be taught, devised intricate methods to spare them the calamity of death—this was their utmost compassion. Yet the common folk refuse to believe, dismissing it as empty words. If it were mere empty words, how could the nine transformations, completed over days, all proceed according to the method? The true ones’ understanding of this cannot be sought through the shallow thoughts of ordinary men.

I delight in the arts of the Dao, traveling far to seek and inquire, undeterred by distance. Each rare teaching I hear brings me joy. Though mocked and ridiculed, I do not take it amiss. Who knows if those to come may not surpass the present? Thus I write this to show those of discernment—not to indulge in the strange or adorn empty speech, nor to spread these words among the world and bind the俗 to belief.

The blazing sun cannot revive withered wood; the highest wisdom cannot transform the basest ignorance. Writings are transmitted for the faithful; affairs are valued by the wise. A farmer wielding a vermilion bow drives away crows; a southern barbarian, given a ceremonial robe, uses it to carry firewood. What can be done for those who do not understand?

The people of the world eat their fill all day yet scarcely apply themselves to the studies of the sages or the cultivation of virtue. They wander idly, frittering away their years. Their pursuits are but glory or profit—some chase game through the wilds, some linger over wine, some drown in beauty and music, some indulge in fine silks, some exhaust their sinews with the bow, some squander their time in gambling. Hearing the words of the supreme Way, they act as if drunk; reading the discourses on the Dao, they doze by day. They neglect their bodies, driving them toward death, unwilling to seek the methods of nurturing life. Instead, they carve away at themselves, sear and scorch, wear themselves ragged, and drown in dissipation.

The man of the Dao treasures his knowledge and keeps it secret, asking nothing of others—why should he force his words upon them? The world often says that if long life could be attained, the sages of old, who possessed both wealth and honor, would have achieved it. Yet none did, so the Way must not exist. They do not realize that the wealthy and honored of old are no different from those of today—both disbelieve and do not seek, both prioritize their immediate desires. How, then, could they attain it?

Should one be unable to fully trust in fate, yet still wish to seek the attainable path of immortality, why hesitate to attempt it? Even a modest success—gaining two or three centuries of life—would far surpass the fleeting span of ordinary men. The affairs of the world are myriad, and the arts of the Dao are more difficult to clarify than any other pursuit. How, then, can one of middling talent presume to declare that the Way of long life does not exist? If we were to dismiss its possibility simply because most do not believe in it, would that not imply that the wise among men are far too few?

Now, if one discerns the intent of the Dao and seeks it alone, must they truly be the most foolish, falling short of all others? Some fear that in pursuing long life, should they fail, they will be mocked as deluded. Yet if one’s own judgment is flawed and the Way of immortality does indeed exist, would they not then be ridiculed by those who have attained it? The sun and moon, though radiant, cannot illuminate every heart—how, then, can one rely solely on isolated belief?

I have examined *The Yellow Emperor’s Scripture of the Nine Cauldrons Divine Elixir*, which states: "The Yellow Emperor consumed it and ascended as an immortal." It further declares: "Though one practices breath control, guiding and pulling, or consumes herbal medicines to extend life, death remains inevitable. Only the divine elixir grants boundless longevity, aligning one’s years with heaven and earth, riding clouds and cranes to ascend and descend the Great Purity." The Yellow Emperor transmitted this to Master Jue, admonishing him: "This Way is of utmost gravity—it must be entrusted only to the worthy. Should one be unfit, though their gold pile high as mountains, do not reveal this Way to them." The recipient was to cast a golden fish into the east-flowing waters as a pledge, swearing an oath in blood. Those without the bone of immortality could neither hear nor witness this Way.

The elixir must be compounded in a renowned mountain, in a place untouched by men, with no more than three companions. First, one must fast for a hundred days, bathe in five fragrances, and maintain utmost purity, avoiding defilement and contact with others. One must also prevent those who disbelieve in the Dao from learning of it, lest they slander the divine medicine and cause it to fail. Through this, an entire household may ascend as immortals, not merely a single person.

Yet the world neglects the divine elixir, placing faith instead in herbal medicines. Herbs and plants rot when buried, dissolve when boiled, and char when burned—they cannot even preserve themselves, how then can they grant life to men? The Nine Elixirs are the essence of long life, beyond the reach of ordinary perception.

The teeming masses, dull and blind, know only to covet wealth and rank—are they not but walking corpses? When compounding the elixir, one must also perform a ritual. The method and diagrams for this rite are recorded in the final scroll of *The Scripture of the Great Purity*.

**The Scripture of the Golden Liquor of Divine Immortality of the Master Embracing Simplicity, Final Scroll**
**On the Divine Elixirs of the Immortals**

The first elixir is named *Dan Hua* ("Cinnabar Splendor"). First prepare *xuanhuang* ("Mystic Yellow"), using realgar water, alum, mercury, *rongguan*, salt, *yushi*, oyster shell, red halloysite, talc, and lead powder—each in quantities of several dozen *jin*. Form these into *liuyi* mud, then fire it for thirty-six days to completion. Ingesting it for seven days grants immortality. Alternatively, knead this elixir with *xuangao* ("Mystic Paste") and place it in a fierce fire; in an instant, it becomes yellow gold. Further, combine 220 *zhu* of it with one hundred *jin* of mercury and fire it for thirty-six days to produce yellow gold. When the gold forms, the elixir is complete. If the gold does not form, reseal the elixir and fire it again for the same number of days—it will invariably succeed.

The second elixir is named *Shen Fu* ("Divine Talisman"). Ingesting it for one hundred days grants immortality. When crossing great waters, apply this elixir to the soles of the feet, and one may walk upon the water. Taking three *daogui* of it causes the Three Corpses and Nine Worms to dissolve and vanish, curing all ailments.

The third elixir is named *Shen Dan* ("Divine Elixir"). Ingesting one *daogui* grants immortality in one hundred days. Even if fed to livestock, their mouths will never again touch wood or die. It also repels the Five Weapons. After one hundred days of ingestion, immortal youths and jade maidens, along with the spirits of mountains and rivers, will attend one, appearing in human form.

The fourth elixir is named *Huan Dan* ("Returning Elixir"). Ingesting one *daogui* grants immortality in one hundred days. Vermilion birds and phoenixes will soar above, and jade maidens will draw near. Combining one *daogui* with one *jin* of mercury and firing it instantly produces yellow gold. Applying this elixir to money or objects ensures their return the same day they are spent. Writing with this elixir upon the eyes of an ordinary person causes all ghosts to flee.

The fifth elixir is named *Er Dan* ("Edible Elixir"). Ingesting it for thirty days grants immortality. Ghosts and spirits will attend, and jade maidens will appear before one.

The sixth elixir is named *Lian Dan* ("Refined Elixir"). Ingesting it for ten days grants immortality. It may also be combined with mercury and fired to produce yellow gold.

The seventh elixir is named *Rou Dan* ("Supple Elixir"). Ingesting one *daogui* grants immortality in one hundred days. Mixing it with the sweat from a washbasin and ingesting it allows even ninety-year-old men and women to bear children. When combined with lead and fired, it becomes yellow gold.

The eighth elixir is named *Fu Dan* ("Subduing Elixir"). Ingesting it for one hundred days grants immortality. Carrying a piece the size of a jujube pit while traveling causes all ghosts to avoid one. Writing with this elixir upon doors and windows prevents all evil spirits and malevolent beings from approaching, and it also repels thieves, tigers, and wolves.

The ninth elixir is named *Han Dan* ("Cold Elixir"). Ingesting one *daogui* grants immortality in one hundred days. Immortal youths and jade maidens will attend, and one may fly lightly without the need for wings.

Of these Nine Elixirs, obtaining even one is sufficient for immortality; there is no need to prepare all of them. The choice depends on one’s preference.

When ingesting the Nine Elixirs, if one wishes to ascend to heaven, one may depart; if one prefers to remain among men, that is also permissible. All may freely enter and exit the realm of the immortals without harm.

There is also the Divine Elixir of the Great Clarity Palace, whose method was transmitted by the Primordial Lord. The Primordial Lord was the teacher of the Old Lord. *The Upper Scripture of the Great Clarity* contains nine chapters: the upper three may not be taught; the middle three are unworthy of transmission in the world and should be sunk into the depths of the Three Springs. The lower three chapters are precisely the three scrolls of the *Elixir Scripture*—upper, middle, and lower.

The Primordial Lord was a great divine immortal. He could harmonize yin and yang, command ghosts and spirits, and ride upon wind and rain, with nine dragons and twelve white tigers at his service. All the immortals of the world were subject to him. Yet he himself said that he had originally studied the Dao and attained his state through ingesting the elixir—it was not innate. How could a mortal man die?

The scripture states: The superior person who attains the Dao ascends to the heavenly offices; the middling person dwells upon Kunlun; the inferior person achieves long life in the world. Foolish people do not believe this, dismissing it as empty words. From dawn to dusk, they engage only in actions that lead to death, never seeking to ascend to heaven—how could they be forcibly granted life? Ordinary people know only fine food, beautiful clothing, music, sensual pleasures, wealth, and rank. Indulging their desires to the fullest, they are but fleeting beings doomed to perish. Take care not to reveal the divine elixir to them, lest they mock the Dao and slander the truth. Transmitting the elixir scripture to the unworthy will bring misfortune upon oneself. If one encounters a person of sincere faith, one may share the compounded elixir with them, but never lightly transmit the method.

What need has one who knows this Dao for the rank of a prince or king? Once the divine elixir is completed, it not only grants long life but can also be used to make gold. Upon producing one hundred *jin* of gold, first perform a grand offering, for which there is a separate method—it is not the same as the ritual for the Nine Cauldrons. The offering must be made by separately designating the gold for each deity: twenty *jin* to Heaven, five *jin* to the Sun and Moon, eight *jin* to the Northern Dipper, eight *jin* to the Great Unity, five *jin* to the Well, five *jin* to the Great Turtle, twelve *jin* to the River Earl, five *jin* to the Earth Altar, and five *jin* each to the spirits of doors, windows, and the household—totaling eighty *jin*. Place the remaining twenty *jin* in a reed sack, and on an auspicious day during a bustling market hour, silently abandon it in a crowded place, then depart without looking back. Only after using one hundred *jin* in this manner may one freely use the gold. If one does not first offer gold to the various spirits, one will surely incur misfortune.

It is further said: The Way of long life does not lie in sacrificial offerings or serving ghosts and spirits, nor in breathing exercises or bending and stretching. The essential method for ascending as an immortal lies in the divine elixir. Knowing it is not easy; practicing it is truly difficult. If you can prepare it, you may attain long life.

In recent times, during the late Han, Lord Yin of Xinye compounded this Great Clarity Elixir and attained immortality.

This individual was originally a Confucian scholar, possessed of literary talent. He composed poems, eulogies for the *Canon of the Elixir*, and a preface, recounting his early Daoist studies and his teacher’s teachings from beginning to end. He listed over thirty acquaintances who had attained immortality through these methods—all clearly documented.

Though this *Great Clarity Elixir* is a minor refinement, it is more difficult to compound than the *Nine-Cauldron Elixir*. Yet it remains the supreme method for ascending to heaven in broad daylight. To prepare it, one must first create *Flower Pool Urine Water*, *Golden Duke’s Yellow Bloom*, *Cinnabar Salt’s Mountain Snow*, *Mysterious White Flying Talisman*, and *Three-Five Divine Water* before kindling the fire.

A single-transformation elixir, when ingested, grants immortality in three years.
A double-transformation elixir, when ingested, grants immortality in two years.
A triple-transformation elixir, when ingested, grants immortality in one year.
A quadruple-transformation elixir, when ingested, grants immortality in half a year.
A quintuple-transformation elixir, when ingested, grants immortality in one hundred days.
A sextuple-transformation elixir, when ingested, grants immortality in thirty days.
A septuple-transformation elixir, when ingested, grants immortality in twenty days.
An octuple-transformation elixir, when ingested, grants immortality in ten days.
A nonuple-transformation elixir, when ingested, grants immortality in a single day.

To refine the nonuple-transformation elixir, place it within the *Divine Crucible*. After the Summer Solstice, expose it to the sun until the crucible grows hot. Then place one *jin* of *Cinnabar Child* beneath the lid, and wait attentively. When the sun’s essence shines upon it, in an instant, all will rise together in radiant splendor—resplendent with five-colored divine light—and transform into *Returned Elixir*. Ingesting a single *knife-point* of it will grant ascent to heaven in broad daylight.

The nonuple-transformation elixir is also sealed and buried in an earthen cauldron, fired with chaff—first gentle heat, then fierce. Each transformation, from the first to the ninth, varies in duration. The fewer the transformations, the fewer the days required, but the elixir’s potency remains insufficient, thus requiring more time for ingestion and delaying immortality. The greater the number of transformations, the more potent the elixir, thus requiring less time for ingestion and hastening immortality.

There is also the *Nine Radiance Elixir*, distinct from the *Nine-Transformation Elixir*, though their methods are largely similar. To prepare it, first combine the various ingredients and refine them through five stones: cinnabar, realgar, white arsenic, azurite, and magnetite. Each stone undergoes five transformations, yielding five colors; the five stones together produce twenty-five colors. One *liang* of each color is stored in separate vessels.

To revive the dead who have not yet been deceased for three days, take a *knife-point* of the green elixir, mix it with water, bathe the corpse, and place another *knife-point* into its mouth—the dead will immediately revive.

To summon a traveling kitchen, mix the black elixir with water and anoint the left hand. Whatever is spoken aloud will instantly appear, capable of manifesting all things under heaven.

To become invisible, foreknow future events, or halt aging, ingest a *knife-point* of the *Yellow Bloom Elixir*—one will attain longevity and cease aging. Sitting, one may perceive events a thousand *li* away, discerning fortune and misfortune as if before one’s eyes. The destinies of all people—prosperity or decline, longevity or early death, wealth or poverty—will be known. These methods are all recorded in the middle scroll of the *Great Clarity*.

There is also the *Five Spirits Elixir Canon* in one scroll, containing five methods. It employs cinnabar, realgar, orpiment, sulfur, azurite, arsenic, magnetite, halite, *Taiyi Yu Yu Root*, *Six-One Clay*, and a *Divine Chamber*. After sacrificial rites, it is compounded and fired for thirty-six days to completion. Additionally, *Five Emperor Talismans*, painted in five colors, can also confer immortality, though they are not as potent as the *Great Clarity* or *Nine-Cauldron Elixirs*.

There is also the *Min Mountain Elixir Method*, discovered by the Daoist Zhang He, who devoted himself to meditation in a stone chamber on Min Mountain. His method involves smelting cold brass to fashion a *Square Vessel*, which collects *Moon Water*. Mercury is then placed over it to capture the essence of the sun’s fire. Long-term ingestion confers immortality.

Another method involves placing elixir in a *Realgar Copper Crucible*, covering it with mercury, and exposing it to the sun for twenty days. After refinement, ingest a *small bean’s* worth with *Well-Flower Water*. Within a hundred days, the blind regain sight, all illnesses are cured, white hair turns black, and lost teeth regrow.

There is also the *Master Wucheng’s Elixir*, which uses *Ba Cinnabar* placed in an eight-inch copper tray. A clay furnace filled with charcoal is arranged with three trenches, and the tray is suspended above. *Stone Sulfur Water* is poured over it, keeping it mud-like. Ingesting it for a hundred days confers immortality.

There is also the *Master Xianmen’s Elixir Method*, which steeps one *jin* of cinnabar in three *dou* of wine for thirty days. Ingesting it for a single day expels the *Three Worms* and all diseases. Ingesting it for three years perfects the Daoist way, and two jade maidens will attend, ready to serve and instantly summon a traveling kitchen. This elixir can also repel malevolent ghosts, vengeful spirits, and the misfortunes of the dead afflicting homes or construction sites. Hang it facing the source of harm, and all will be well.

There is also the *Instant Elixir*, which has nine variants, resembling the *Nine-Cauldron Elixir* but inferior in potency. Its essential method involves taking realgar, burning it, and pouring it into a copper vessel, which is then inverted over three-year-old pure bitter wine. After a hundred days, the vessel will grow red nodules several *fen* long, or five-colored *langgan* jade. Refining and ingesting it also grants longevity.

It is further said that mixing the first sprouts of *Cuscuta* (whose roots resemble rabbits) and extracting their juice to blend with this elixir allows instantaneous transformation at will. Combined with *Vermilion Grass*, a single dose enables one to ride the void and travel upon clouds. *Vermilion Grass* resembles a small mulberry or jujube tree, standing three to four *chi* tall, with entirely red branches and leaves. Its stem resembles coral, and it grows beneath cliffs in famous mountains. When cut, its sap flows like blood. If jade, the *Eight Stones*, gold, or silver are cast into it, they can be kneaded like clay and, over time, dissolve into water.

chunks.original_text: 以金投中，则名为金浆。 以玉石投之，则名玉醴。 服之长生。 又有取伏丹法，云天下诸水有名丹者，若南阳之丹水之属也。 其中皆有丹鱼，常赤。 以夏至十日夜伺之，丹鱼必浮於水侧，赤光生，上照赫如火也，网而取之可得。 得之虽多，勿尽取也。 割取其血，以涂足下，则可步行水上，长居渊中。 又有赤松子丹法，取之千岁蒙汁，及樊桃汁搔丹，着不津之器中，缣密盖其口，埋入地二尺，百日，绞梓木赤实取汁，和而服之j令人面目须发，皆赤长也。 昔中黄仙人有赤须子者，岂非服此药乎。 又白石生丹法，取峻岩之上。 千岁松叶，金菊花，狭苓，狭神，成散，华池水服之，能致神灵。 又以相叶阴乾百日，炼蜜丸散，服久得寿身轻。 又取乌毂之未生毛羽者，以真丹和牛肉，以吞之，至长，其毛羽皆赤。 乃杀之，阴乾百日，并毛羽梼，服一刀圭，百日，得寿五百岁。 又康风子丹法，用羊乌鹳血，合少室天雄汁，和丹内鹄卵中，漆之，内云母水中，百日化为赤水，服一合辄益寿百岁，服一升寿千岁。 又崔文子丹法，内丹惊卵腹中蒸之，服延年，长服亦不死。 又刘子丹法，以丹内玄水液中百日，紫色，握之不污手。 又和之以云母水，内管中漆之，投井中，百日化为赤水。 服一合得百岁，久服长生。 又乐子长丹法，以曾青、铅丹合汞及丹砂，着铜莆中，用瓦滑石封之，白沙中蒸之，八十日。 服如小豆子，三年内仙矣。 又李文丹法，以白素裹丹，以竹汁煮之，名曰红泉，乃浮汤上蒸之，合以玄水服之，一合一年仙也。 又尹子丹法，以云母水和丹，密封，置金华池中，一年出，服一刀圭，尽一斤，得五百岁。 又太一召魂丹法，所用用五石，及封之以六一泥，似九丹也。 长於起卒、死，三日以还者，拆齿内一丸，与硫黄，俱以水送之，令入喉中，即活。 活者皆见使者持节召之也。 又采女丹法，以兔血和丹，与蜜蒸之百日，服之如梧子者一丸，日三至百一日，有神女江人来侍之，乃可役使也。 又稷丘子丹法，以清酒、麻油、百华醴、龙膏和，封以六一泥，糠火媪之十日成。 服如小豆，乃尽剂，得五百岁。 又墨子丹法，用汞及五色石之液，於铜器中火熬之，以铁匕搅之，十日还为丹。 服之一刀圭，万病去身，长服不死。 又张子和丹法，用铅汞砂、曾青水合封之，蒸之於赤黍米中，八十日成。 以枣膏和丸之，服如大豆，百日寿五百岁。 又绮里季丹法，先飞取五石玉尘，合以丹砂汞，内大铜管中，煮之百日，五色。 服之仙飞。 以铅百斤，以药百刀圭，合火之成白银。 以雄黄水和而火之，百日成黄金。 金或太刚者，以楮汁煮之，或太柔者，以白梅煮之，尽一剂得长生。 又王桂丹法一，以华池和丹，以曾青、吭黄末覆盖之，内莆中，以回於之五十日，服百日，玉女六甲六丁神女来侍之，可使，知天下之事。 又肘后丹法，以金华和丹，以莆盛之，乾瓦封之，蒸八十日，取如小豆，置盘中，向日和之，其光上与日连。 服如小豆，长生矣。 以投丹阳铜中，火之成金。 又一法，以柚汁和丹，服之百日，长生。 又李公丹法，用真丹及五石之水，各一升，和令如泥，釜中火之三十六日，出和以石硫黄液，服之十年，与天地相毕。

chunks.original_text: 抱朴子日：金液，太一所服而仙者，不喊九丹矣。 合之用古秤黄金一斤，并玄明、龙膏骨、太一旬首中石水紫游女玄水液金化石丹砂，封之成水。 其真经云：金液入口，身皆金色。 老君受之於元君，日此道至重，百世一出，藏之石室，合之皆须斋戒，不与俗人相来往，於名山之侧，束流水上，立起精室，百日成，服一两便升仙。 若未欲去世，且作地仙之士者，但斋百日耳。 若欲升天，皆先断谷一年，乃服也。 若半两，则长生不死，万害百毒不能复伤之，可以畜妻子，致家居官秩，在意所欲，元所禁也。 若后欲升天者，乃斋戒，更服一两，便飞仙矣。 又金液为威喜巨胜之法，取金液及水银左味，合煮之三十日，出黄土瓯盛，封以六一泥，置之猛火上，炊之卒时，化为丹。 服如小豆大，便仙。 以此丹一刀圭，粉水银一斤，即成银。 又取此丹一斤，置猛火扇之，即化为赤金而流，名曰丹金。 以涂刀剑，辟五兵万里。 以此丹金为盘碗，饮食其中，令人长生。 以引承日月，当得神液，如方诸之得水也，饮之不死。 以金液和黄土，内六一泥瓯中，猛火炊之，尽成黄金，中用、也。 复以火炊之，皆化为丹。 服之如小豆，可以入名山大水，为地“仙。 以一刀圭粉水银，立成银。 以银一两，和铅一斤，皆变成银。 《金液经》云：投金八两，於东流水，饮血为誓，乃告口诀。 不知本法，盗其方而作之，终不得成也。 凡人有至信者，可以药与之。 不可轻传其书，必两受其殃。 天监人甚近，而人不知耳。 抱朴子日：九丹诚为仙药之上法，然令作之，所用杂药极多，若四方清通者，市之可具。 若九域分隔，则物不可得也。 又当起火时，当昼夜数，十伺候火力，不可令失其适，勤苦至难，故不及合金液之易也。 合金液唯金为难。 得古秤秤一斤，於今二斤，率不过直二十余万钱。 其所用杂药差易，又不起火，但以置华池中，日数足便成耳。 都合之所用三十万，而得一剂，可足令八人仙也。 然不中稍少合者，其气力不足以相化成，如酿数升米酒无成也。 抱朴子日：其次则有饵黄金，虽不及金液然亦足，远不比於他药也。 或陕淤觅＂革眸及齐舞之＂，一蜘既佩皮口治之，或刻酒磁石消之，或可引如布，或立成水服之，或有禁忌不及金液也，或以雄黄雌黄等合饵之，可以引之张之如皮也，皆地仙法耳。 银及蚌中大珠，皆可化为水服之，然须长服不可供，故不及金液。 抱朴子曰：金此金液及九丹，既当用钱，又宜入山绝人事，故能为之者少。 且千万人中，时当有一人得其经，者一，故谓作道书者，略无说金丹者也。 第一禁勿令俗人不信道者，谤讪毁之，必不成也q郑君言：所以尔者，合作此大药裁、皆、当祭。 祭则太一元君、九丹老君，玉女皆来监省。 作药者若不绝入幽僻之地，令俗闻恶人亦得经过闻见，则诸神责作药者，不遵承经戒，致令恶人有言毁之，则不复佑助之，而邪黑得进，药必不成。 必入名山之中，斋戒百日，不食五辛生鱼，不与俗人相见尔，乃可作大药。 须成乃常斋，不但初作药时斋也。 郑君言左君告之云：诸小小山，皆不可於其中，作金液神丹也。 凡小山皆无正神为主，多是千岁老物、血食之鬼。

Ge Hong said: The *Jin Ye* (Golden Liquid), which the Supreme Unity consumed to ascend as an immortal, surpasses even the Nine Elixirs. To compound it, take one *jin* of yellow gold by the ancient scale, along with *xuanming*, dragon’s marrow bone, *Taiyi xunshou zhong* stone water, purple-trailing maiden’s dark water liquid, and cinnabar transformed by gold. Seal these to form a liquid.

The authentic scripture states: When the *Jin Ye* enters the mouth, the body turns golden. The Old Lord received this from the Primordial Lord, who declared, “This Way is most weighty—emerging but once in a hundred generations. It is concealed in a stone chamber. To compound it, one must fast and abstain, shun all contact with the profane, and erect a purified chamber beside a mountain stream flowing east. After a hundred days, it is complete. Ingesting one *liang* grants ascent as an immortal. If one does not yet wish to depart the world but seeks only to become an earthbound immortal, a hundred-day fast suffices. To ascend to heaven, one must first abstain from grains for a year before ingesting it. Taking half a *liang* ensures longevity without death, rendering one invulnerable to all harm and a hundred poisons. One may then keep a wife and children, establish a household, hold office, and pursue desires without restriction—nothing is forbidden. Should one later wish to ascend to heaven, one must fast and abstain anew, then ingest another *liang* to become a flying immortal.

The *Jin Ye* also serves as the method for *Wei Xi Ju Sheng* (Majestic Joy and Mighty Victory). Take *Jin Ye* and mercury of the left flavor, boil them together for thirty days, then store in an earthenware jar sealed with *liuyi* mud. Place it over a fierce fire and heat until it transforms into an elixir. Ingesting a dose the size of a small bean grants immortality. With one *daokui* of this elixir, powder a *jin* of mercury to turn it into silver. Taking one *jin* of this elixir and fanning it with a fierce fire transforms it into flowing red gold, called *Dan Jin* (Elixir Gold). Coating blades and swords with it repels all weapons for ten thousand *li*. Fashioning bowls and plates from this *Dan Jin* and eating from them grants longevity. Drawing forth the essences of the sun and moon yields divine liquid, like obtaining water with a *fangzhu*, and drinking it ensures immortality. Mixing *Jin Ye* with yellow earth and placing it in a *liuyi* mud jar, then heating it with a fierce fire, transforms it entirely into yellow gold, which may be used for all purposes. Heating it again transforms it back into an elixir. Ingesting a dose the size of a small bean allows one to enter famous mountains and great waters as an earthbound immortal. With one *daokui*, powder mercury to instantly form silver. Mixing one *liang* of this silver with one *jin* of lead transforms all into silver.

The *Scripture of the Golden Liquid* states: Cast eight *liang* of gold into an eastward-flowing stream, swear an oath in blood, and then recite the oral incantation. Without knowing the original method, one who steals the formula and attempts it will never succeed. Only those of utmost faith may be given the medicine. The scripture must not be lightly transmitted, or both giver and receiver will suffer calamity. Heaven’s surveillance of mortals is close, though they remain unaware.

Ge Hong said: The Nine Elixirs are indeed the supreme method for immortality, yet their preparation requires an abundance of miscellaneous ingredients. If the four directions are unobstructed, these may be procured in markets. But if the nine regions are divided, the materials become unattainable. Moreover, when kindling the fire, one must tend it day and night, carefully regulating its intensity to avoid error—a labor of extreme difficulty. Thus, it is not as simple as compounding the *Jin Ye*. The only challenge in preparing *Jin Ye* is obtaining the gold. One *jin* by the ancient scale weighs two *jin* today, costing no more than twenty thousand coins. The other ingredients are relatively easy to acquire, and no fire is required—one merely places them in the *Hua Chi* (Flower Pond) until the allotted days are complete. The total cost amounts to thirty thousand coins for one dose, sufficient to immortalize eight people. However, if the quantity is even slightly reduced, the potency will be insufficient for transformation, like brewing wine from a few measures of rice—it will never ferment.

Ge Hong said: Next is the method of ingesting yellow gold. Though not equal to the *Jin Ye*, it far surpasses other medicines. Some refine it with *maoyu* or *qimu* and *qiwu*, or wear it in a leather pouch, or dissolve it with lodestone wine, or draw it out like cloth, or instantly transform it into water for ingestion. Some methods have prohibitions not found in the *Jin Ye* process. Combining it with realgar, orpiment, and the like allows one to stretch and mold it like leather—all these are methods for earthbound immortality. Silver and large pearls from clams may also be transformed into water for ingestion, but they require prolonged consumption and are difficult to sustain, thus inferior to the *Jin Ye*.

Ge Hong said: The *Jin Ye* and Nine Elixirs demand wealth and seclusion in the mountains, away from worldly affairs, so few can undertake them. Among ten thousand, perhaps one may obtain the scriptures, hence those who compose Daoist texts rarely discuss the golden elixir. The foremost prohibition is that skeptics and unbelievers must not slander or defame it, or it will surely fail.

Master Zheng said: The reason is this—when compounding such great medicines, one must perform sacrifices. During the sacrifice, the Supreme Unity, Primordial Lord, Nine Elixir Old Lord, and Jade Maidens all come to oversee. If the alchemist does not retreat to a secluded place, allowing the profane or wicked to witness the process, the gods will reproach the alchemist for failing to uphold the scriptural precepts, permitting evil tongues to defame the work. They will withdraw their protection, allowing demonic forces to interfere, and the elixir will not succeed. One must enter a famous mountain, fast for a hundred days, abstain from the five pungent foods and raw fish, and avoid all contact with the profane before attempting the great medicine. chunks.original_text: 此辈皆邪气，令合药不成，不为人作福，但能作祸，善试道士。 道士虽当作卫以辟身，及弟子然，亦或能坏人药也。 今之医家，每合好药好膏，皆不欲鸡犬、妇人、小儿见之。 若被诸物犯之，便用之不验。 又染彩者恶，恶目者见之皆失色。 况神丹大药乎。 是以古人道士合作神仙大药，必入名山，不止凡山之中，正为此也。 又按仙经，可以精思合作仙药者，有华山、泰山、霍山、恒山、嵩高山、少室山、昊山、终南山、王屋山、女几山、地肺山、抱犊山、安丘山、潜山、青城山、绥山、云台山、罗浮山、阳驾山、黄金山、鳌祖山、天台山、四望山、盖竹山，此皆是正神在其中，其中或有地仙之人，上皆生芝草，可以避大兵大水，不但於中以合药也，若有道者登之，则此山神必助之为福也，其药必成。 若不得登此诸山者，海中大岛屿亦可合药。 若会稽之束翁洲，纷屿及徐州之羊莒洲，黍洲光洲、郁洲皆其次也。 今中国名山不可得至，江东名山可往之者，唯霍山，在晋安长沙。 太山、太白山，在束阳。 四望山、天台山、盖竹山、括苍山，悉在会稽。 抱朴子曰：余忝大臣之子孙，虽才不足以经国治物，然俦类之好进趣之业，而所知不能远余者，多挥翮云汉，耀景辰霄者矣。 余所以绝庆吊於乡党，弃当世荣华，必欲速登名山，成所着子书。 次则合神药，以规长生。 故俗人莫不怪余之委桑梓，背清涂，而躬耕林薮，手足胼胝，谓余有狂惑之疾也。 然道与世反，事不并兴。 若不废人问之务，何得修如此之志乎。 见之诚了，执之必定者，亦何惮於毁誉，岂移於沮劝哉。 聊书其心，亦示将来之同志者。 云想后之断金之徒，所有指弃者J 亦与余不异耳。 小神丹方，用真丹三斤，白蜜六斤，搅合，日暴，煎之，令可丸。 日一服如麻子许，十丸，未一年，白须更黑，齿落更生，身体润泽。 长服之，老翁成年少，长生不死。 小饵丹法，丹一斤梼下筛，淳苦酒三升，淳漆三升，凡三物相得，微火上煎令可丸。 服如麻子，三丸，日再服，三十日，腹中百病愈，三尸去。 服之百日，肌骨强坚。 服千日，司命削去死籍，与天地相保，日月相望，改形易容，变化无常，日中无影，乃别有光也。 小饵黄金法，消金内清酒中，约二百过，出入即沸，握之出指问，令如泥。 若不沸，及泥之不出指问，即消之，内清酒中无数也。 成，服之如弹子丸一枚，亦可一丸分为小丸，服之三十日，无寒温，神人玉女事之。 银亦得可饵，与金同法服。 此二物能居名山石室中者，一年轻举矣。 止人问亦地仙，勿妄传。 两仪子饵黄金法，堵负革脂三斤，淳苦酒一升，取黄金五两，置器中煎之，土炉，以金置脂中，百入百出者，苦酒亦然。 餐一斤金，寿蔽天地，食半斤金，寿三千岁。 食五两金，一千二百岁。 金无多少，便可饵之，当以王相日服之作之，神良。 勿传非人。 传示非人，令药不成不神。 欲去当服丹砂。 抱朴子神仙金汋经卷下竟

These beings are all imbued with malevolent *qi*, causing alchemical compounds to fail. They bring no fortune to men, only misfortune, and delight in testing Daoists. Though Daoists may employ protective measures to shield themselves and their disciples, such entities may still spoil the elixir. Even today, physicians compounding fine medicines or salves avoid the gaze of chickens, dogs, women, or children. Should such beings violate the process, the remedies lose their efficacy. Moreover, dyers despise those who observe their work, and those with the evil eye may cause colors to fade—how much more so for the divine elixir and great medicine? Thus, the ancients and Daoists seeking to compound the grand elixirs of immortality invariably entered renowned mountains, never mere ordinary peaks, precisely for this reason.

Furthermore, according to the *Immortals’ Scriptures*, the mountains where one may concentrate the mind to compound elixirs of transcendence include: Mount Hua, Mount Tai, Mount Huo, Mount Heng, Mount Songgao, Mount Shaoshi, Mount Wu, Mount Zhongnan, Mount Wangwu, Mount Nüji, Mount Difei, Mount Baodu, Mount Anqiu, Mount Qian, Mount Qingcheng, Mount Sui, Mount Yuntai, Mount Luofu, Mount Yangjia, Mount Huangjin, Mount Ao Zu, Mount Tiantai, Mount Siwang, and Mount Gaizhu. These mountains all harbor true spirits, and some are home to earthbound immortals. Above, they bear *zhi* mushrooms, and within, one may evade great wars and floods. Yet their purpose extends beyond elixir-compounding: should a man of the Dao ascend them, the mountain spirits will surely aid him in attaining fortune, and his medicine will succeed. For those unable to reach these mountains, the great islands of the sea may also serve for compounding elixirs. Among them, the secondary choices include Dongweng Isle in Kuaiji, Fen Isle, Yangju Isle in Xu Province, Shu Isle, and Guang Isle, as well as Yu Isle.

In the present age, the renowned mountains of the Central Kingdom are inaccessible, but in Jiangdong, the following may be visited: Mount Huo in Jin’an and Changsha; Mount Tai and Mount Taibai in Dongyang; Mount Siwang, Mount Tiantai, Mount Gaizhu, and Mount Kuocang, all in Kuaiji.

The Master of Embracing Simplicity says: Though I am the descendant of great ministers, my talents are insufficient to govern the realm or manage affairs. Yet among my peers, many have soared to the clouds and shone in the celestial vault, surpassing my humble attainments. Thus, I have severed ties of mourning and celebration with my hometown, forsaken the glory of the present age, and resolved to swiftly ascend the famous mountains to complete the works I have authored. Next, I shall compound the divine elixir to pursue longevity. For this, the worldly deem me mad—abandoning my homeland, turning from the clear path, and toiling in the forests and marshes, my hands and feet calloused. They say I suffer from delusion. Yet the Dao runs counter to the world, and affairs cannot be pursued in tandem. If I did not set aside worldly duties, how could I cultivate such aspirations? When one’s vision is clear and resolve unwavering, what fear is there of slander or praise? How could discouragement or persuasion sway me? I record these thoughts to share with those of like mind in the future.

I imagine that those who later form bonds of unbreakable fellowship will share my convictions. The formula for the Minor Divine Elixir: Take three *jin* of true cinnabar and six *jin* of white honey, mix them, expose to sunlight daily, and simmer until pliable enough to form pills. Consume one pill the size of a sesame seed daily, ten pills in total. Within a year, white hair will turn black, lost teeth will regrow, and the body will become lustrous. With prolonged use, the elderly will regain their youth, and one may attain immortality.

The method for the Minor Elixir of Cinnabar: Grind one *jin* of cinnabar into fine powder, then combine with three *sheng* of pure bitter wine and three *sheng* of pure lacquer. Simmer the three ingredients over a low flame until they can be formed into pills. Consume three pills the size of sesame seeds, twice daily. After thirty days, the hundred diseases of the abdomen will be cured, and the Three Corpses expelled. After a hundred days, the muscles and bones will grow strong and firm. After a thousand days, the Controller of Destinies will erase one’s name from the register of death, and one will be safeguarded by Heaven and Earth, gazing upon the sun and moon. One’s form and countenance will transform, assuming myriad shapes, and at midday, one will cast no shadow, for one will possess a radiance of one’s own.

The method for the Minor Elixir of Gold: Dissolve gold in clear wine, repeating the process approximately two hundred times, until the mixture froths upon insertion and removal. Knead it until it oozes between the fingers like mud. If it does not froth or fails to seep between the fingers, continue dissolving it in clear wine without limit. Once complete, consume a pill the size of a bullet. Alternatively, divide one pill into smaller portions. After thirty days of consumption, one will be free from cold and heat, and divine beings and jade maidens will attend to you. Silver may also be consumed in the same manner as gold. Those who dwell in the stone chambers of famous mountains and consume these two substances will ascend lightly within a year. Even if one remains among men, one will become an earthbound immortal. Do not transmit this recklessly.

The Twofold Principle Master’s method for consuming gold: Take three *jin* of *dufu* leather fat and one *sheng* of pure bitter wine. Place five *liang* of gold in a vessel and simmer over a clay stove. Insert and remove the gold into the fat a hundred times; do the same with the bitter wine. Consuming one *jin* of gold grants a lifespan coextensive with Heaven and Earth; half a *jin* grants three thousand years; five *liang* grants twelve hundred years. Regardless of quantity, gold may be consumed. Prepare and consume it on a day when the celestial stems and branches are in harmony, and the efficacy will be divine. Do not transmit this to the unworthy. Should it be shared with the unfit, the medicine will fail to achieve its potency. To cease consumption, take cinnabar.

Here ends the second scroll of the *Master of Embracing Simplicity’s Scripture of Divine Immortals’ Alchemical Gold*.
